articles.headline: Violence Erupts Between Fatah and Hamas
articles.snippet: Security personnel of the Fatah faction went on a rampage after Hamas gunmen attacked the headquarters of the Fatah-dominated security forces.
articles.abstract: Security personnel of the Fatah faction went on a rampage after Hamas gunmen attacked the headquarters of the Fatah-dominated security forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, June 12 — Hundreds of Palestinian security personnel loyal to the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, went on a rampage Monday night in the West Bank town of Ramallah, attacking the parliament and cabinet buildings controlled by his rivals in the Hamas-led government.

articles.headline: Police Struggles in New Orleans Raise Old Fears
articles.snippet: With the city's force recovering from Hurricane Katrina, memories of its incompetent, brutal past have returned.
articles.abstract: With the city's force recovering from Hurricane Katrina, memories of its incompetent, brutal past have returned.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, June 9 — Within the Police Department here, the SWAT team is known as The Final Option. Before Hurricane Katrina, it was assigned to the city's worst crimes, and as residents return, it is once again kicking in the doors at the worst drug dens and engaging in shootouts with violent offenders.

articles.headline: As DVD Sales Slow, Hollywood Hunts for a New Cash Cow
articles.snippet: DVD sales are expected to grow just 2 percent this year, a far cry from the double-digit growth the movie industry enjoyed just two years ago.
articles.abstract: DVD sales are expected to grow just 2 percent this year, a far cry from the double-digit growth the movie industry enjoyed just two years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After more than half a decade as Hollywood's savior, the DVD is looking a little tired — and the movie studios, for once, are having trouble coming up with a sequel.

articles.headline: Broad Economic Worries Drive a Global Sell-Off
articles.snippet: Fears about higher interest rates, rising inflation and a slowing economy sent stocks lower, with emerging markets taking the biggest hit.
articles.abstract: Fears about higher interest rates, rising inflation and a slowing economy sent stocks lower, with emerging markets taking the biggest hit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fears about higher interest rates, rising inflation and a slowing economy sent stocks sharply and broadly lower yesterday, with emerging markets taking the biggest hit.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Prisoners Gain in Suit Attacking Lethal Injection
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court opened the door for inmates to challenge the way most states carry out lethal injections.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court opened the door for inmates to challenge the way most states carry out lethal injections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 12 — The Supreme Court opened the door Monday for death-row inmates to challenge the way most states carry out executions by lethal injection.

articles.headline: U.S. Muslims Confront Taboo on Nursing Homes
articles.snippet: Many Muslim families are trying to reconcile Islamic teachings on caring for elders with the modern realities.
articles.abstract: Many Muslim families are trying to reconcile Islamic teachings on caring for elders with the modern realities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN PARK, Minn. — As a founder of the growing Shiite Muslim community here, Hussein Walji oversaw the building of the area's first mosque. He directed construction of its youth center, and followers hailed him as a visionary for adding an auditorium for ecumenical functions like the M&M picnic for Muslims and Methodists.

articles.headline: Police Struggles in New Orleans Raise Old Fears
articles.snippet: Within the Police Department here, the SWAT team is known as The Final Option. Before Hurricane Katrina, it was assigned to the city's worst crimes, and as residents return, it is once again kicking in the doors at the worst drug dens and engaging...
articles.abstract: Within the Police Department here, the SWAT team is known as The Final Option. Before Hurricane Katrina, it was assigned to the city's worst crimes, and as residents return, it is once again kicking in the doors at the worst drug dens and engaging in shootouts with violent offenders.     But the team is also running dangerously low on firepower. Flooding ruined 300 of its guns, its bullet-resistant shields and the bulk of its ammunition, none of which have been replaced more than nine months after the hurricane. The 40-man team has had to borrow body armor from suburban forces, and the Police Department is lining up corporate sponsors to contribute more.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, June 9 - Within the Police Department here, the SWAT team is known as The Final Option. Before Hurricane Katrina, it was assigned to the city's worst crimes, and as residents return, it is once again kicking in the doors at the worst drug dens and engaging in shootouts with violent offenders.

articles.headline: Somber Tone and Protest as U.A.W. Convenes
articles.snippet: The United Automobile Workers' convention opened here Monday with leaders and members in a familiar fighting mood, but with a new battle plan aimed at protecting what they have rather than gaining new ground.     The change reflected the falling f...
articles.abstract: The United Automobile Workers' convention opened here Monday with leaders and members in a familiar fighting mood, but with a new battle plan aimed at protecting what they have rather than gaining new ground.     The change reflected the falling fortunes of Detroit's automakers, a new reality that the union's president, Ron Gettelfinger, laid out for members both in his speech and in a written report that the U.A.W. issued on Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS, June 12 - The United Automobile Workers' convention opened here Monday with leaders and members in a familiar fighting mood, but with a new battle plan aimed at protecting what they have rather than gaining new ground.

articles.headline: Violent Crime Rises in U.S.
articles.snippet: Violent crime increased for the first time in four years. Page A16.
articles.abstract: Violent crime increased for the first time in four years. Page A16.
articles.lead_paragraph: Violent crime increased for the first time in four years. Page A16.

articles.headline: Prisoners Gain in Suit Attacking Lethal Injection
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court opened the door Monday for death-row inmates to challenge the way most states carry out executions by lethal injection.     In its unanimous opinion, the court expressed no view on the constitutionality either of lethal injection...
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court opened the door Monday for death-row inmates to challenge the way most states carry out executions by lethal injection.     In its unanimous opinion, the court expressed no view on the constitutionality either of lethal injection in general or of the specific procedures and combination of chemicals that a Florida inmate, Clarence E. Hill, and numerous others around the country have recently challenged in federal court.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 12 - The Supreme Court opened the door Monday for death-row inmates to challenge the way most states carry out executions by lethal injection.

articles.headline: Broad Economic Worries Drive a Global Sell-Off
articles.snippet: Fears about higher interest rates, rising inflation and a slowing economy sent stocks sharply and broadly lower yesterday, with emerging markets taking the biggest hit.     In the United States, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.3 perce...
articles.abstract: Fears about higher interest rates, rising inflation and a slowing economy sent stocks sharply and broadly lower yesterday, with emerging markets taking the biggest hit.     In the United States, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.3 percent, erasing all of its gains for the year and closing at its lowest level since November. The Nasdaq fell more than 2 percent and the Dow Jones industrial average fell almost 1 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fears about higher interest rates, rising inflation and a slowing economy sent stocks sharply and broadly lower yesterday, with emerging markets taking the biggest hit.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: David (Car) Has Better Chance Against Goliath (S.U.V.)
articles.snippet: A large number of sport utility vehicles and pickups that have been redesigned to reduce the threat they pose in collisions with smaller cars are now reaching the road.      The changes to sport utilities and pickups are being made to prevent them...
articles.abstract: A large number of sport utility vehicles and pickups that have been redesigned to reduce the threat they pose in collisions with smaller cars are now reaching the road.      The changes to sport utilities and pickups are being made to prevent them from running over smaller vehicles in a crash. A recent study showed that the modifications, which automakers initially resisted but then agreed to adopt by late 2009, sharply reduced the number of deaths of people in cars struck by these vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 9 - A large number of sport utility vehicles and pickups that have been redesigned to reduce the threat they pose in collisions with smaller cars are now reaching the road.

articles.headline: U.S. Muslims Confront Taboo on Nursing Homes
articles.snippet: As a founder of the growing Shiite Muslim community here, Hussein Walji oversaw the building of the area's first mosque. He directed construction of its youth center, and followers hailed him as a visionary for adding an auditorium for ecumenical ...
articles.abstract: As a founder of the growing Shiite Muslim community here, Hussein Walji oversaw the building of the area's first mosque. He directed construction of its youth center, and followers hailed him as a visionary for adding an auditorium for ecumenical functions like the M&M picnic for Muslims and Methodists.      But even family members find Mr. Walji's latest expansion uncomfortably American: he is developing plans for an assisted living and nursing complex in this Minneapolis suburb.
articles.lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN PARK, Minn. - As a founder of the growing Shiite Muslim community here, Hussein Walji oversaw the building of the area's first mosque. He directed construction of its youth center, and followers hailed him as a visionary for adding an auditorium for ecumenical functions like the M&M picnic for Muslims and Methodists.

articles.headline: As DVD Sales Slow, Hollywood Hunts for a New Cash Cow
articles.snippet: After more than half a decade as Hollywood's savior, the DVD is looking a little tired -- and the movie studios, for once, are having trouble coming up with a sequel.      DVD sales represent more than half of the revenue studios generate from mos...
articles.abstract: After more than half a decade as Hollywood's savior, the DVD is looking a little tired -- and the movie studios, for once, are having trouble coming up with a sequel.      DVD sales represent more than half of the revenue studios generate from most of their movies. But those sales are expected to grow just 2 percent this year, a far cry from the double-digit growth the industry enjoyed just two years ago. High-definition DVD's were supposed to pick up the slack, but technical delays and a thorny format war between camps led by Sony and Toshiba have dampened expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES - After more than half a decade as Hollywood's savior, the DVD is looking a little tired -- and the movie studios, for once, are having trouble coming up with a sequel.

articles.headline: A Daily Pill to Combat Impotence?
articles.snippet: Get ready for one-a-day Cialis. Icos Corporation, which together with Eli Lilly markets Cialis, the No. 2 impotence drug, says it plans later this year to ask the Food and Drug Administration for approval of a once-daily version of the medicine. I...
articles.abstract: Get ready for one-a-day Cialis. Icos Corporation, which together with Eli Lilly markets Cialis, the No. 2 impotence drug, says it plans later this year to ask the Food and Drug Administration for approval of a once-daily version of the medicine. In May, Icos applied to European drug regulators for approval of the once-daily pill.
articles.lead_paragraph: Get ready for one-a-day Cialis. Icos Corporation, which together with Eli Lilly markets Cialis, the No. 2 impotence drug, says it plans later this year to ask the Food and Drug Administration for approval of a once-daily version of the medicine. In May, Icos applied to European drug regulators for approval of the once-daily pill.

articles.headline: Violence Erupts Between Fatah and Hamas
articles.snippet: Hundreds of Palestinian security personnel loyal to the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, went on a rampage Monday night in the West Bank town of Ramallah, attacking the parliament and cabinet buildings controlled by his rivals in the Hamas-led g...
articles.abstract: Hundreds of Palestinian security personnel loyal to the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, went on a rampage Monday night in the West Bank town of Ramallah, attacking the parliament and cabinet buildings controlled by his rivals in the Hamas-led government.      The attack by forces from the Fatah faction loyal to Mr. Abbas, who fired bullets at the buildings and set them on fire, came after Hamas gunmen attacked the Gaza headquarters of the Fatah-dominated security forces with rockets and grenades.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, June 12 - Hundreds of Palestinian security personnel loyal to the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, went on a rampage Monday night in the West Bank town of Ramallah, attacking the parliament and cabinet buildings controlled by his rivals in the Hamas-led government.
